searchDocs.title: new​
searchDocs.content: </> Wrapper.new( Class: Class<T>?, Tag: string, Options: Options? ) → Wrapper<T> Constructs a Wrapper object. local wrapper = Wrapper.new()

searchDocs.title: GetAll​
searchDocs.content: </> Wrapper:GetAll() → {[Instance ]: T} Returns all of the currently tracked objects. local objects = wrapper:GetAll()

searchDocs.title: GetObject​
searchDocs.content: </> Wrapper:GetObject(Inst: Instance ) → T? Gets the object associated with the given instance. local object = wrapper:GetObject(someInstance) object:DoSomething()

searchDocs.title: GetObjectByGUID​
searchDocs.content: </> Wrapper:GetObjectByGUID(GUID: string) → T? Gets the object associated with the given GUID. local guid = "342dcb0a-11b0-4119-abd8-ef8a100816b4" local object = wrapper:GetObjectByGUID(guid) object:DoSomething()

searchDocs.title: AwaitObject​
searchDocs.content: </> Wrapper:AwaitObject( Inst: Instance , Timeout: number? ) → Promise wrapper:AwaitObject(someInstance) :andThen(function(object) object:DoSomething() end) :catch(warn)

searchDocs.title: Call​
searchDocs.content: </> Wrapper:Call( Object: T, Method: string, ...: any ) → any Calls a method on the object associated with the given instance. local object = wrapper:GetObject(someInstance) wrapper:Call(object, "DoSomething")

searchDocs.title: CallAll​
searchDocs.content: </> Wrapper:CallAll( Method: string, ...: any ) → () Calls a method on all objects. local randomVariable = 10 wrapper:CallAll("DoSomething", randomVariable)

searchDocs.title: Apply​
searchDocs.content: </> Wrapper:Apply(Inst: Instance ) → () Creates a new object for an instance and starts tracking it. Also provides the object with a trove that will be cleaned up upon destruction. local object = wrapper:Apply(someInstance) if object then object: DoSomething() end

searchDocs.title: Revoke​
searchDocs.content: </> Wrapper:Revoke(Inst: Instance ) → () Manually cleans up an object. Note, this does not destroy the object (though that is another way to force cleanup). local object = wrapper:Apply(someInstance) -- cleans up the instance in the wrapper wrapper:Revoke(someInstance) -- you could also destroy the instance, thereby invoking the tag removed event someInstance:Destroy -- also cleans up

searchDocs.title: RevokeAll​
searchDocs.content: </> Wrapper:RevokeAll() → () Revokes all wrapped objects. wrapper:RevokeAll()

searchDocs.title: Destroy​
searchDocs.content: </> Wrapper:Destroy() → () Cleans up the entire Wrapper, destroying all tracked objects and resources. wrapper:Destroy()
